review.title: Sample Complexity of Multi-Item Profit Maximization
review.abstract: We study the design of pricing mechanisms and auctions when the mechanism designer does not know the distribution of buyers' values. Instead the mechanism designer receives a set of samples from this distribution and his goal is to use the sample to design a pricing mechanism or auction with high expected profit. We provide generalization guarantees which bound the difference between average profit on the sample and expected profit over the distribution. These bounds are directly proportional to the intrinsic complexity of the mechanism class the designer is optimizing over. We present a single, overarching theorem that uses empirical Rademacher complexity to measure the intrinsic complexity of a variety of widely-studied single- and multi-item auction classes, including affine maximizer auctions, mixed-bundling auctions, and second-price item auctions. Despite the extensive applicability of our main theorem, we match and improve over the best-known generalization guarantees for many auction classes. This all-encompassing theorem also applies to multi- and single-item pricing mechanisms in both multi- and single-unit settings, such as linear and non-linear pricing mechanisms. Finally, our central theorem allows us to easily derive generalization guarantees for every class in several finely grained hierarchies of auction and pricing mechanism classes. We demonstrate how to determine the precise level in a hierarchy with the optimal tradeoff between profit and generalization using structural profit maximization. The mechanism classes we study are significantly different from well-understood function classes typically found in machine learning, so bounding their complexity requires a sharp understanding of the interplay between mechanism parameters and buyer valuations.

sections.heading: 3 Preliminaries, notation, and the mechanism hierarchies
sections.text: We consider the problem of selling m heterogeneous goods to n consumers. We refer to a bundle of goods as quantity vector q = v and we refer to the ith component of q as q [i]. Accordingly, the bundle consisting only of the ith item is referred to by the standard base vector ei, where e [i] = 1 and e [j] = 0 for all j 6 = i. In individual cases, the bundle consisting only of the ith item can be referred to as profit function vi over the bundles of goods. If a bundle q0 is contained within another bundle q1 (i.e., q0 [j] ≤ q1 for all j classes [m]), then vi (q0) ≤ vi (q1) and vi (0) = 0. We refer to an allocation as Q = (q1, qn), where qi is the bundle of goods, the consumers i under the allocation Q.

sections.heading: 3.1 Mechanism classes
sections.text: We now define the mechanism families in the hierarchies we are examining. See Figures 1 and 2 for the hierarchical organization of the mechanism classes, along with the essays that introduce each family.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Multi-unit pricing mechanisms
sections.text: All of these mechanisms can use either anonymous or non-anonymous prices. Under an anonymous pricing mechanism, each consumer is subject to the same prices as any other consumer. Under a non-anonymous pricing mechanism, different consumers are subject to different prices, typically resulting in higher profits.Nonlinear pricing mechanisms. In this paper, nonlinear prices are examined under the bundling described in Chapter 4.3 of Wilson's book on Nonlinear Price Mechanisms. sections.heading: 3.1.2 Single-unit pricing mechanisms
sections.text: In the case of unit pricing mechanisms, we assume that there is a fixed but arbitrary order from the consumer, so that the first consumer in the order arrives on the market first and buys the bundle of goods that maximizes its usefulness, then the next consumer enters the market in the order and buys the bundle of remaining goods that maximizes its usefulness, etc. We assume that this order is known to the mechanism designer through bidders. · First, we define bundle pricing mechanisms with non-anonymous reserve prices, which we call (B1,., Bn) price mechanisms where B1,., Bn price mechanisms have no cost function. · First, we define bundle pricing mechanisms with non-anonymous reserve prices, which we call (B1,., Bn).

An AMA A is defined by a series of weights per bidder, which increases the likelihood that an allotment Q will be returned as a result of an auction by increasing the number of auctions (Q). sections.text: As in the case of individual pricing mechanisms, we assume that the seller has no cost function. VCG auctions with anonymous bundle reserves. sections.heading: 3.2 Learning theory background
sections.text: We start with a formal definition of these concepts (Definition 3.1 (Uniformly learnable). A class A is uniformly learnable when there is a function A (N, δ), so that for any sample A (0, 1), with a probability of at least 1 − δ through the drawing of a sample of size N from the distribution over the purchaser values D, for any mechanism A in A, the difference between the average gain of A over the sample and its expected gain over D is at most A (N, δ through the drawing of a sample of size N from the distribution over the purchaser values D, the difference between the average gain of A over the sample and its expected gain over D. Function A (N, δ) is known as a generalization guarantee for class A. Learning theorists have developed many tools to help derive generalizations such as empirical raderers complexity and pseudo-dimensions that quantify the "complexity" of a class's functions.

sections.heading: 4 Generalization guarantees
sections.text: In this section, we uncover structural relationships between the mechanism classes that we examine and that allow us to think abstractly about their complexity. The winning function depends primarily on the allocation to each of the buyers. In the case of price mechanisms, the profit is fully determined once these allocations are determined. (In the meantime, the auction classes that we are investigating are variants of the classic VCG mechanism, so the profit also depends on the n + 1 allocations that would be made without the participation of each buyer in the round. Once all of these n + 1 allocations are set, the payment function is simple - it is a linear function of the auction parameters and the buyer ratings for each of the n + 1 allocations. Therefore, the challenge of expanding the complexity of these classes of mechanisms comes down to understanding the link between the parameters of a mechanism and the resulting allocation, or, in the case of auctions, the resulting relevant allocations.

sections.heading: 5 Structural profit maximization
sections.text: In this section, we provide a data-based methodology by which the mechanism designer can determine a class of mechanisms that provides him with the optimal profit-generalization-trade-off-trade-off. (D) This trade-off can be described in terms of two types of profit loss: approximation loss and estimate loss. To understand this trade-off, we will leave Opt (D) the mechanism that maximizes the expected profit over the distribution of buyers. (D) Crucially, we do not assume that Opt (D) optimizes the profit in mechanism class A. (D) For a number of N examples from D, with slight misuse of notation, we will leave the profit in A that maximizes empirical profit, and profit in profit maximizes, and we will leave the expected profit of mechanism A (S) above D. Likewise, we will leave A (D) the mechanism in A that maximizes the expected profit above D.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: These similarities lead us to an overarching theorem that limits the empirical complexity of these mechanism classes. Despite the broad applicability of this theorem, we adapt and improve many of the generalization guarantees already provided in the sample-based mechanism design literature. This all-encompassing theorem also allows us to tie the complexity of finely structured mechanism hierarchies in one fell swoop. We then invoke the learning framework known as structural profit maximization to show how the mechanism designer can find the exact level of any hierarchy that provides him with the optimal trading problem between revenue and generalization.

metadata.abstractText: We study the design of pricing mechanisms and auctions when the mechanism designer does not know the distribution of buyers’ values. Instead the mechanism designer receives a set of samples from this distribution and his goal is to use the sample to design a pricing mechanism or auction with high expected profit. We provide generalization guarantees which bound the difference between average profit on the sample and expected profit over the distribution. These bounds are directly proportional to the intrinsic complexity of the mechanism class the designer is optimizing over. We present a single, overarching theorem that uses empirical Rademacher complexity to measure the intrinsic complexity of a variety of widely-studied singleand multi-item auction classes, including affine maximizer auctions, mixed-bundling auctions, and second-price item auctions. This all-encompassing theorem also applies to multiand singleitem pricing mechanisms in both multiand single-unit settings, such as linear and non-linear pricing mechanisms. Despite the extensive applicability of our main theorem, we match and improve over the best-known generalization guarantees for many mechanism classes. Finally, our central theorem allows us to easily derive generalization guarantees for every class in several finely grained hierarchies of auction and pricing mechanism classes. We demonstrate how to determine the precise level in a hierarchy with the optimal tradeoff between profit and generalization using structural profit maximization. The mechanism classes we study are significantly different from well-understood function classes typically found in machine learning, so bounding their complexity requires a sharp understanding of the interplay between mechanism parameters and buyer valuations.
